content.question:
The gene encoding the catalytic subunit of cytochrome c oxidase (<math alttext="MT dash C O 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>T</mi><mtext>-</mtext><mi>C</mi><mi>O</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>) is found in the mitochondria of all animals. The gene evolves rapidly and is often used to determine evolutionary relationships among species. Table 1 shows DNA sequence differences among four animal species (<math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>).
Which of the following cladograms best represents the evolutionary relationships among the four species?

choices.label: The figure shows a cladogram of four species, labeled 1 through 4. The cladogram is in the shape of a V, with two main lines that fan out to the upper left and upper right from where they join at the bottom. All lines end at the same level at the top of the cladogram and have the numbers 1 through 4 at their tips. The left line is labeled 2. The right line is labeled 4. A line labeled 1 branches off the right line about one-third of the way from the right line’s top end. Then an additional line labeled 3 branches off this new line about halfway along its length.

The figure shows a cladogram of four species, labeled 1 through 4. The cladogram is in the shape of a V, with two main lines that fan out to the upper left and upper right from where they join at the bottom. All lines end at the same level at the top of the cladogram and have the numbers 1 through 4 at their tips. The left line is labeled 1. The right line is labeled 4. A line labeled 2 branches off the left line about one-third of the way from the left line’s top end. A line labeled 3 branches off the right line about one-third of the way from the right line’s top end.

The figure shows a cladogram of four species, labeled 1 through 4. The cladogram is in the shape of a V, with two main lines that fan out to the upper left and upper right from where they join at the bottom. All lines end at the same level at the top of the cladogram and have the numbers 1 through 4 at their tips. The left line is labeled 2. The right line is labeled 4. A line labeled 1 branches off the right line about one-third of the way from the right line’s top end. A line labeled 3 branches off the right line halfway between the line 1 branch and the right line’s top end.

The figure shows a cladogram of four species, labeled 1 through 4. The cladogram is in the shape of a V, with two main lines that fan out to the upper left and upper right from where they join at the bottom. All lines end at the same level at the top of the cladogram and have the numbers 1 through 4 at their tips. The left line is labeled 4. The right line is labeled 1. A line labeled 2 branches off the left line about one-third of the way from the left line’s top end. A line labeled 3 branches off the left line, below the line 2 branch and about two-thirds of the way from the left line’s top end.

content.answer: The figure shows a cladogram of four species, labeled 1 through 4. The cladogram is in the shape of a V, with two main lines that fan out to the upper left and upper right from where they join at the bottom. All lines end at the same level at the top of the cladogram and have the numbers 1 through 4 at their tips. The left line is labeled 2. The right line is labeled 4. A line labeled 1 branches off the right line about one-third of the way from the right line’s top end. Then an additional line labeled 3 branches off this new line about halfway along its length.

skill.text: 2.B: Explain relationships between characteristics of biological models in both theoretical and applied contexts.
